revision.text:
{{coord|40.438948|N|79.947705|W|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Infobox NRHP | name = Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens | nrhp_type = | designated_other1_name = City of Pittsburgh Historic Structure | designated_other1_date = December 26, 1972<ref name="CPHD list">{{cite web | url = http://www.phlf.org/historic-plaque-program/local-historic-designations/ | title = Pittsburgh History and Landmarks Foundation: Local Historic Designations| date =2002-05-01 | accessdate = 2009-07-11 }}</ref> | designated_other1_abbr = CPHS | designated_other1_link = List of City of Pittsburgh historic designations | designated_other1_color = black | designated_other1_textcolor=gold | designated_other2 = PHLF | designated_other2_date = 1970<ref name="PHLF list">{{cite web | url = http://www.phlf.org/plaques/locallist.html | title = Internet Archive: Pittsburgh History and Landmarks Foundation: PHLF Plaques & Registries| date=2007-01-27 | accessdate = 2009-07-11 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070127092030/http://www.phlf.org/plaques/locallist.html |archivedate=2007-01-27}}</ref> | image = Phipps Conservatory winter 2015 welcome center.jpg | caption = Main entrance to Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens | location= [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] | area = 15 acres | built =1893 | architect= [[Lord & Burnham]] | architecture= [[Victorian architecture|Victorian greenhouse]] | added = November 13, 1976 | refnum=76001598<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2006a}}</ref> }} '''Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens''' is a [[botanical garden]] set in [[Schenley Park]], [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States]]. It is a City of Pittsburgh historic landmark and is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.arch.state.pa.us/pdfs/H001763_01B.pdf | title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory - Nomination Form: Phipps Conservatory | year=1976 | accessdate=2010-06-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
The gardens were founded in 1893 by steel and real-estate magnate [[Henry Phipps, Jr.|Henry Phipps]] as a gift to the City of Pittsburgh. Its purpose is to educate and entertain the people of Pittsburgh with formal gardens (Roman, English, etc.) and various species of exotic plants ([[Arecaceae|palm trees]], [[Succulent plant|succulents]], [[bonsai]], [[Orchidaceae|orchids]], etc.). Currently, the facilities house elaborate gardens within the fourteen room conservatory itself and on the adjoining grounds. In addition to its primary [[Flora (plants)|flora]] exhibits, the sophisticated glass and metalwork of the [[Lord & Burnham]] conservatory offers an interesting example of [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] greenhouse architecture.
Phipps is one of the "greenest" facilities in the world.<ref name="sustainablelandscapes"/> The entrance pavilion of the Phipps Conservatory has silver-level [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] certification.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://new.usgbc.org/projects/phipps-conservatory-and-botanical-garden|title=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Garden|publisher=U.S. Green Building Council|accessdate=January 24, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130123051425/http://new.usgbc.org/projects/phipps-conservatory-and-botanical-garden|archive-date=2013-01-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Its greenhouse production facility has received Platinum certification, the first and only greenhouse to be so certified.<ref name="greenhouse">{{cite web|url=http://wesa.fm/2012/07/05/phipps-production-greenhouse-attains-leed-platinum|title=Phipps Production Greenhouse Attains LEED Platinum|first=Josh|last=Raulerson|publisher=WESA.fm|date=July 5, 2012|accessdate=January 24, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130217120538/http://wesa.fm/2012/07/05/phipps-production-greenhouse-attains-leed-platinum|archivedate=February 17, 2013|df=}}</ref> Moreover, the [[Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens#Center for Sustainable Landscapes|Center for Sustainable Landscapes]], designed to be as environmentally sustainable as possible, is also LEED Platinum certified, and [[Zero-energy building|produces all of its own energy]].
== History == [[File:Phipps Conservatory 1893.jpg|thumb|The Conservatory in 1893]] The Phipps Conservatory was founded in 1893 as a gift from [[Henry Phipps, Jr.]] to the City of [[Pittsburgh]].<ref name="history-1893">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/phipps-history/1893|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Year: 1893, A Gift for Pittsburgh|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The Conservatory was designed by [[Lord & Burnham]], for a fee of $100,000. The glasshouse, then consisting of nine display rooms, was completed in August 1893, one year after construction began. On December 7, 1893, the Phipps Conservatory was opened to the public, displaying many plants from the [[World's Columbian Exposition]] in [[Chicago]].{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
[[File:Phipps Conservatory Aquatic Gardens 1915.jpg|thumb|left|A postcard postmarked 1915 illustrates the Aquatic Garden.]] Sometime after 1910, the first of the Aquatic Gardens was built. A second pool would be installed in 1939.<ref name="history-1915">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/phipps-history/1915/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Year: 1915, The Early Years|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref>
In 1970, the Conservatory was declared a [[List of Pittsburgh History and Landmarks Foundation Historic Landmarks|Historic Landmark]] by the [[Pittsburgh History and Landmarks Foundation]].<ref name="PHLF list" /> In 1976, the Phipps Conservatory was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]].<ref name="nris"/>
In 1993, the Phipps Conservatory, which had been run by the City of Pittsburgh since 1893, became a privately managed, while city owned, [[non-profit organization]].<ref name="history-1993">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/phipps-history/1993/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Year: 1993, Transformation|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref>
In October 2003, Phipps announced an expansion project. The first phase, a [[Green building|green]] engineered Welcome Center topped by a neo-Victorian dome, was designed by IKM Incorporated, and completed in 2005. The Production Greenhouses and a Tropical Forest Conservatory were completed in 2006.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} [[File:Phipps Conservatory 36.jpg|thumb|The Welcome Center, completed in 2005, features a neo-Victorian dome illuminated by a [[Dale Chihuly|Chihuly]] chandelier.]] The Tropical Forest conservatory has a different theme every three years, beginning with the country of Thailand. In addition to a "Research Forest Station" and a "Healer's Hut" (designed to educate visitors about various cultural topics), there are two waterfalls, several bridges, a stream, and a wide variety of plants from bamboo, orchids and frangipani to plants of economic, cultural, and horticultural value to the people of Thailand. The second theme is "Headwaters of the Amazon," which opened in early 2009. {{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
[[Image:Phipps2.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|An example of a [[Dale Chihuly]] art glass installation at the Phipps Conservatory in 2007]] In 2007, Phipps teamed with glass artist [[Dale Chihuly]] and his [[Tacoma, Washington|Tacoma]]-based team of glass blowers. They worked together to create a marriage of hand-blown glass and living plants. Following the closing of the exhibit in February, the conservatory retained four prominent pieces (the Welcome Center [[chandelier]], the hanging gold star in the Desert Room, the [[celadon]] and purple gilded Fiori in the Tropical Fruit and Spice Room and the bronze, apricot and chartreuse Ikebana in the Palm Court) and subsequently purchased 26 smaller pieces for its permanent collection including six multicolored Macchia (wavy, shell-like bowls), thirteen amber Cattails and seven Paintbrushes, all of which are installed in the Palm Court. The total Chihuly collection is valued at $1.2 million.<ref>[http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/08192/895985-437.stm PG: Chihuly works will become permanent fixtures at Phipps, July 10, 2008]</ref>
In 2009, Phipps teamed with another glass artist [[Hans Godo Frabel]] to create another stunning exhibit titled "Gardens and Glass." Unlike the Chihuly pieces, Frabel's work is more realistic, although still whimsical at times. Highlights of this exhibit include Longfellows, intricate glass orchid and lotus plants and various clowns (balancing on either glass playing cards or colored glass balls.) This collaboration was on display until January 2010.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
== Indoor Gardens ==
=== Palm Court === [[File:Phipps Conservatory 14.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.8|Paper cranes on display in the Palm Court]]
The Palm Court is the first room visitors see after entering the Conservatory through the main entrance. The Victorian-inspired room contains many species of [[Arecaceae|palm trees]].<ref name="palm">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/palm-court/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Palm Court|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The room contains the original dated plaque from the Conservatory's opening as well as numerous glass installations by [[Dale Chihuly]]. To accommodate the palm trees, the Palm Court has a high glass peak.
The original wood and annealed glass in the Palm Court had deteriorated to a point for the need of emergency stabilization in 2008.<ref name="palmcourtrenovations">{{cite web|url=http://www.montgomerysmithinc.com/?p=463|publisher=Montgomery Smith Inc.|title=Phipps Conservatory – Palm Court Renovations|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> Renovations began in 1992 and included replacing the upper wood and glass vent sash with aluminum and safety glass, and replacing the vertical wood and glass components with new replicated aluminum extrusions and safety glass glazing to match the original specifications exactly.
=== Serpentine Room === [[File:Phipps Conservatory winter 2015 Serpentine Room.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|The Serpentine Room during the winter flower show]] The Serpentine Room is located west of the Palm Court, connecting it to the Fern Room.<ref name="serpentine">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/serpentine-room/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Serpentine Room|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The exhibits in the room change with the season for different shows and special exhibits. The room is named for its curved brick-walled pathway. Plants are lined along either side of the pathway, as well as suspended from the peaked ceiling.
The room was originally known as the Border Garden, which was redesigned as the present-day Serpentine Room during an 18-month period of extensive renovations starting in 1978.<ref name="history-1978">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/phipps-history/1978/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Year: 1978, Transformation|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref>
=== Fern Room === [[File:Encephalartos ferox at the Phipps Conservatory.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.8|''[[Encephalartos ferox]]'' in the Fern Room. It produces a large red cone once every five or six years.]] The Fern Room is located in the west wing at the intersection of the Serpentine Room, the Orchid Room, and the Stove Room.<ref name="fern">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/fern-room/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Fern Room|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The room contains many [[fern]]s, as well as [[cycad]]s and other ground plants on which ferns commonly grow. The dominant species in the room are representative of the [[Triassic]], during which ferns and cycads were common as flowering plants would not evolve until millennia later. Some species include [[Encephalartos munchii|Munch's cycad]], [[Encephalartos altensteinii|Eastern Cape cycad]], [[Zululand cycad]], [[Queen sago]], [[Staghorn fern]], [[Australian tree fern]], [[Tasmanian tree fern]], [[Pyrrosia lingua|tongue fern]], [[Aglomorpha meyeniana|bear's paw fern]], and [[Davallia fejeensis|rabbit foot's fern]].<ref name="plants">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/plant-collections|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Plant Collections|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref>
=== Orchid Room === [[File:Phipps Conservatory 10.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|The Orchid room]] The Orchid Room is located in the north part of the west wing.<ref name="orchid">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/orchid-room-1/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Orchid Room|accessdate=2015-10-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150910224249/https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/orchid-room-1|archivedate=2015-09-10|df=}}</ref> The room contains many [[orchid]]s. This includes the miniature orchids and the Barbara Tisherman [[Cypripedioideae|Slipper Orchid]] Collection, curated in collaboration with the Orchid Society of Western Pennsylvania. Also on display is the unique [[Phalaenopsis]] Frank Sarris orchid, named for the founder of [[Sarris Candies]], a trustee and benefactor of the Conservatory.
The room originated with a donation of 800 rare orchids in 1931 from Charles D. Armstrong, owner of the [[Armstrong Cork Company]].<ref name="history-1931">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/phipps-history/1931/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Year: 1931, The Early Years|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The orchids were then valued at $50,000.
=== Stove Room === [[File:Phipps Conservatory Stove Room Rain Chain.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.5|The Stove Room]] The Stove Room is located in the south part of the west wing.<ref name="stove">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/stove-room/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Stove Room|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> From spring to fall, the room contains many butterflies and the exhibit is known as the Butterfly Forest. The plants in the room are representative of the deep tropics, and the room is maintained at a temperature of {{convert|80|F|C}} during the day and {{convert|70|F|C}} during the night.
=== South Conservatory === [[File:Phipps Conservatory 19.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|The fall Garden Railroad exhibit in the South Conservatory]] The South Conservatory is located south of the Palm Court.<ref name="south">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/south-conservatory/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=South Conservatory|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The room houses seasonal flower shows. Since 1999, during fall and winter months, the room transforms into the Garden Railroad exhibit, in which [[Rail transport modelling|miniature train]]s wind among a variety of small plants.<ref name="history-1999">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/phipps-history/1999/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Year 1999: Transformation|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref>
Originally called the Economic Room, the South Conservatory was built between 1896 and 1897 as a gift from Henry Phipps.<ref name="history-1928">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/phipps-history/1928/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Year 1928: The Early Years|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> It was then remodelled in the 1930s, during which time the room was partitioned to separate the Gallery and Tropical Fruit and Spice rooms.
=== Tropical Fruit and Spice Room === [[File:Phipps Conservatory Spice Room.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.8|The tropical fruit and spice room]] The Tropical Fruit and Spice Room is located west of the South Conservatory.<ref name="tropical">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/tropical-conservatory/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Tropical Fruit and Spice Room|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The room contains tropical and sub-tropical fruits, nuts, and spices such as [[citrus]] fruits, [[banana]]s, [[allspice]], [[papaya]]s, [[cinnamon]] and [[coffee]]. The marble basin in the center of the room features a [[Dale Chihuly]] glass sculpture in purple and celadon.
=== Tropical Forest Conservatory === [[File:Phipps Conservatory Tropical Forest.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|The Tropical Forest Conservatory.]] The Tropical Forest Conservatory, located south of the South Conservatory, is the largest indoor display area of the conservatory. <ref name="tropicalforest">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/tropical-fruit-spice-room/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Tropical Forest Conservatory|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The room features a different region every three years, and contains man-made waterfalls, winding pathways, a fish pond, and interactive learning stations. it is also the site of many of the public programs and special events at the Conservatory. As of 2015, the region features the Tropical Forest Congo exhibit.<ref name="congo">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/calendar/detail/tropical-forest-congo|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Tropical Forest Congo|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref>
The Tropical Forest Conservatory opened on December 6, 2006.<ref name="iisbe">{{cite conference|url=http://iisbe.org/iisbe/sbc2k8/teams/SBC08_world/SBC08_USA/SBC08_USA_OFFICE_Conservatory.pdf||conference=World Sustainable Building Conference 2008|title=Tropical Forest Conservatory, Pittsburgh, PA, USA|publisher=International Initiative for a Sustainable Built Environment}}</ref> The Tropical Forest Conservatory has several interesting features, which make it extremely energy-efficient. It has "[[earth tubes]]" running underground to help cool the tropical forest and a [[solid oxide fuel cell]], which efficiently produces 5 kW of electricity from natural gas. In addition, there are computer-controlled shades that block excess sunlight from entering the structure and also help to insulate it at night. The roof is also computer-controlled and many of the glass panes can be opened.
=== Gallery Room === [[File:Phipps Conservatory Gallery Room.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.8|The farmer's market at the Gallery Room]] The Gallery Room is located east of the South Conservatory.<ref name="gallery">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/the-gallery/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Gallery Room|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The room contains didactic displays for children, such as the imaginary [[farmer's market]], where children can play and learn about healthy food.
In the 1950s and 1960s, the room was known as the Modern Room, and featured contemporary room and garden scenes.<ref name="history-1956">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/phipps-history/1956/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Year: 1956, Growth and Change|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref>
=== Sunken Garden === [[File:Phipps Conservatory winter 2015 Sunken Garden.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|The Sunken Garden during the winter flower show]] The Sunken Garden is located east of the Palm Court, connecting it to the Victoria Room.<ref name="sunken">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/sunken-garden/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Sunken Garden|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The room is furnished with fountains, hanging baskets, and sunken beds. The plants in the room vary with season. The room has changed several times over the decades. It has been known, at different times, the Cascade Garden featuring a [[Modern architecture|modern]] cascading waterfall; the Charleston Garden featuring an [[antebellum architecture|antebellum]]-themed display with a Southern mansion façade; and, more recently, a [[Japanese Garden|Japanese-style garden]].<ref name="history-1963">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/phipps-history/1963/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Year: 1963, Growth and Change|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref>
=== Desert Room === [[File:Phipps Conservatory Desert Room.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.8|The Desert Room]] The Desert Room is located south of the Sunken Garden.<ref name="desert">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/desert-room/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Desert Room|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The room contains plant life that thrive in a desert climate, such as [[cacti]] and other [[succulent plant]]s. A glass chandelier named Desert Gold Star by [[Dale Chihuly]] can also be found in the room. Some species include the [[Joshua tree]], [[saguaro]], [[Parkinsonia|palo verde]], [[Ferocactus cylindraceus|fire barrels]], [[cape aloe]], [[Dioscorea macrostachya|tortoise shell plant]], [[Boophane disticha|bushman poison bulb]], [[Cyphostemma bainesis|African tree grape]], [[Agave tequilana|sunrise tequila agave]], and [[shaving brush tree]].<ref name="plants"/>
The Desert Room opened in 1902 as the Cacti House.<ref name="cacti">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/phipps-history/1902/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Year: 1902, A Gift for Pittsburgh|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> When it first opened, guests could only look at the display garden over a terrace. In the late 1930s, the room was redesigned so that visitors could walk through it.
=== Victoria Room === [[File:Phipps Conservatory 30.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|The Victoria Room]] The Victoria Room is located in the east wing, connecting the Broderie Room, the East Room, and the Sunken Garden.<ref name="victoria">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/victoria-room/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Victoria Room|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The room features a large central pond containing an interactive fountain.
=== Broderie Room === [[File:Phipps Conservatory winter 2015 Broderie Room.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.8|The Broderie Room during the winter show.]] The Broderie Room, also known as the ''{{lang|fr|Parterre de Broderie}}'' which translates to "flowerbed of embroidery", is located in the south part of the east wing.<ref name="broderie">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/broderie-room/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Broderie Room|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The garden is modelled after the formal gardens of French chateaux during the reign of [[Louis XIV]], and is a popular setting for wedding ceremonies and photo shoots. The room opened in 1939 and was originally called the Cloister Garden.<ref name="history-1939">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/phipps-history/1939/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Year: 1939, the Early Years|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> In 1966, the room was redesigned as the present-day Broderie Room.
=== East Room === [[File:Phipps Conservatory East Room with Japanese Garden exhibit.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|The [[Japanese garden]] installation in the East Room]] The East Room is located in the north part of the east wing.<ref name="east">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/east-room/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=East Room|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The room contains streams and waterfalls. The displays change with season. {{Clear}}
== Outdoor Gardens ==
=== Rooftop Edible Garden === [[File:Phipps Conservatory 27.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.8|The Rooftop Edible Garden]]
The Rooftop Edible Garden is located between the Desert Room and the Tropical Forest Conservatory.<ref name="rooftop-edible-garden">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/rooftop-edible-garden/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Rooftop Edible Garden|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> It contains several edible [[vegetable]]s and [[fruit]]s. The outdoor demonstration space produces fresh produce for the cafeteria in the Welcome Center and serves as a site of hands-on learning for children's camps and youth programs.
=== Japanese Courtyard Garden ===
The Japanese Courtyard Garden is located between the Desert Room and the Gallery Room.<ref name="japanese">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/japanese-courtyard-garden/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Japanese Courtyard Garden|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> It contains a [[Japanese garden]] and several [[bonsai]]. The Garden was installed in 1991 and was designed by [[Hoichi Kurisu]].<ref name="history-1991">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/phipps-history/1991/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Year: 1991, Transformation|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref>
=== Children's Discovery Garden === [[File:Phipps Conservatory winter 2015 Discovery Garden.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.8|Discovery Garden during the winter 2015 light show]] The Children's Discovery Garden is located between the Stove Room and the Tropical Spices room.<ref name="childrens-discovery">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/childrens-discovery-garden/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Children's Discovery Garden|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The Garden contains areas designed to attract birds, butterflies, and bees. It also includes a bog garden, a sensory garden, and various outdoor spaces to entertain and educate children.
=== Outdoor Garden === [[File:Phipps conservatory outdoor gardens gate.JPG|thumb|left|upright=0.8|Gate to the Outdoor Garden]] The Outdoor Garden is located to the northwest of the main building complex.<ref name="outdoor">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/outdoor-garden/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Outdoor Garden|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The garden contains many smaller gardens and plant collections, including an herb garden, a medicinal garden, perennials, ferns and dwarf conifers.
The original hardscape was constructed by [[Works Progress Administration]] in 1935 and persists to this day.<ref name="history-1986">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/phipps-history/1986/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Year: 1986, Transformation|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The garden was originally known as the Perennial Garden, which was transformed into the Outdoor Garden in 1986.
=== Botany Hall === [[File:Phipps Hall of Botany.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.8|The Phipps Hall of Botany]] The Botany Hall, across from [[Panther Hollow Bridge]], features a small garden containing walkways, curved benches, and a fountain.<ref name="botanyhall">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/botany-hall/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Botany Hall|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> The Botany Hall was funded, in 1901, by [[Henry Phipps, Jr.|Henry Phipps]] to be used by local teachers looking to enhance class trips to the glasshouse.<ref name="history-1901">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/phipps-history/1901/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Year: 1901|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> It was renovated in the late 1990s and continues to serve as a site for many educational programs and events.
=== Aquatic Garden === [[File:Phipps Conservatory 7.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|The Aquatic Garden]] The Aquatic garden is located on the east side of the Conservatory outside of the Victoria Room.<ref name="aquatic">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/aquatic-gardens/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Aquatic Garden|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> During the summer, the two pools are filled with tropical water plants and floating flora. One of the pools features a statue of [[Neptune (mythology)|Neptune]], the Roman god of the sea, which was presented to Phipps shortly after our glasshouse opened in 1893. The northern pool was constructed sometime between 1910 and 1915, and the southern one was added in 1939.<ref name="history-1915" /> {{Clear}}
== Center for Sustainable Landscapes == The Center for Sustainable Landscapes (CSL) is a building on the Conservatory grounds, located south of the Tropical Forest Conservatory, that is designed to be environmentally sustainable.<ref name="center">{{cite web|url=https://phipps.conservatory.org/visit-and-explore/explore/online-tour/center-for-sustainable-landscapes/|publisher=Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens|title=Center for Sustainable Landscapes|accessdate=2015-10-24}}</ref> Opened in December 2012, the building produces all of its own energy and treats and reuses all water captured on site. The exhibits in the building include informational signs, an interactive kiosk, and art exhibits. The building also contains a classroom for children.
The CSL has received a [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|Platinum LEED certification]] along with fulfilling the [[Living Building Challenge]] for [[Zero-energy building|net-zero energy]],<ref name="sustainablelandscapes">{{cite news|url=http://www.popcitymedia.com/devnews/phipps052312.aspx|title=Development News: Phipps' Center for Sustainable Landscapes opens today, to be greenest building in the world|newspaper=[[Pop City]]|first=Andrew|last=Moore|date=May 23, 2012|accessdate=January 24, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130121132129/http://popcitymedia.com/devnews/phipps052312.aspx|archivedate=January 21, 2013|df=}}</ref> Additionally, the CSL is the first and only building to receive [http://www.sustainablesites.org/certified-sites/phipps Four Stars Sustainable SITES Initiative] certification for landscaping projects. These honors and certifications make the CSL one of the 'greenest' buildings in the world.<ref name="Phipps Conservatory's Center for Sustainable Landscapes one of the 'greenest' buildings in the world">{{cite news|last1=Pitz|first1=Marylynne|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/news/environment/2015/03/11/Pittsburgh-s-Phipps-Conservatory-center-is-greenest-of-green-buildings/stories/201503110080|accessdate=2015-04-05|agency=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=2015-03-11|title=Phipps Conservatory center is greenest of green buildings}}</ref> {| |[[File:Phipps Conservatory 22.jpg|thumb|The Center for Sustainable Landscapes]] |[[File:Phipps Conservatory 23.jpg|thumb|Water capture and treatment at the Center for Sustainable Landscapes]] |[[File:Phipps Conservatory 24.jpg|thumb|Solar panels at the Center for Sustainable Landscapes]] |}
== References == {{Reflist|25em}}<!--added under references heading by script-assisted edit--> *{{cite book | author=Toker, Franklin | title=Pittsburgh: An Urban Portrait | location=Pittsburgh | publisher=[[University of Pittsburgh Press]] | origyear=1986| year=1994 | isbn=0-8229-5434-6}}
== External links == {{Portal|Pittsburgh}} {{commons category|Phipps Conservatory & Botanical Gardens}} *[http://www.phipps.conservatory.org/ Phipps Conservatory Website] *[http://www.ikminc.com/ IKM Incorporated Website] *[http://www.gigapan.org/viewGigapan.php?id=248 Gigapan of Phipps display of Dale Chihuly: IIkebana, 2007] *[http://www.gigapan.org/viewGigapan.php?id=203 Gigapan of Phipps display of Dale Chihuly: River of Glass, 2007] *[http://www.gigapan.org/viewGigapan.php?id=211 Gigapan of Phipps display of Dale Chihuly: Blue Marlins, Cobalt Fiori, Cobalt Reeds and Niijima Floats, 2007]
Video *[http://www.growingagreenerworld.com/episode104/ Growing a Greener World: Phipps Conservatory-The Greenest in the World] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080715193247/http://www.wqed.org/ondemand/onq.php?cat=19&id=62 WQED onQ: Phipps Tropical Forest: Thailand]

{{Infobox Newspaper | name = Pittsburgh Business Times | image = | caption = | type = Weekly Newspaper | format = | foundation = August 31, 1981 | ceased publication = | price = | owners = | publisher = Evan Rosenberg | editor = Jennifer Beahm | maneditor = Mike Larson | staff = | language = English | political = | circulation = 11,708{{cite web|url=http://abcas3.accessabc.com/ecirc/busform.asp|title=ABC|publisher=}} (2013) | headquarters = 45 S. 23rd Street
Suite 200
Pittsburgh, PA 15203 | sister newspapers = Business Journals | oclc = | ISSN = | website = [http://www.pittsburgh.bizjournals.com/ Pittsburgh Business Times] }} The '''''Pittsburgh Business Times''''' is a diversified business media company serving [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]]. It publishes daily stories on its website and social networks, and a weekly edition available in print and online. It is published by the [[American City Business Journals]]. Published since August 31, 1981{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IbRRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Rm4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6876,6328517|title=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com}} it was founded by the Business Journal Publications Company which merged the paper with the rival ''Pittsburgh Business Journal'', owned by [[Scripps-Howard]], on March 21, 1985. They combined operations by April 1 of that year. In 1986, Business Journal Publications was acquired by [[American City Business Journals]].{{cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/139605115/|title=St. Louis Post-Dispatch from St. Louis, Missouri on September 30, 1986 · Page 31|publisher=}} The paper was sold in 1988.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZuMhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fmMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=997,2715835|title=The Pittsburgh Press - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com}} American City Business Journals reacquired the ''Business Times'' in 1996 with purchase of CityMedia Inc.[http://www.bizjournals.com/kansascity/stories/1996/07/01/story4.html American City Business Journals agrees to buy six weeklies] {{Portal|Pittsburgh|Journalism}} ==External links== *[http://www.pittsburgh.bizjournals.com/ Official site] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Pittsburgh}} {{Advance Publications}} [[Category:American business newspapers]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Pittsburgh]] [[Category:1981 establishments in Pennsylvania]]

{{refimprove|date=November 2016}} {{Underlinked|date=June 2016}}
[[File:Post Mart logo.png|thumb|Company logo]]
'''Post Mart''' is a joint-venture between [[China Post Group]] and U.S.-owned China Horizon Investments Group.
Post Mart provides consumer goods to people in rural China using the existing China Post network of hundreds of thousands of village postal stations as well as a network of distribution centers.
In January 2016 China Horizon Investments sued China Post for fraud and breach of contract in relation to this venture.<ref>{{cite news |last=Freifeld |first=Karen |date=13 January 2016 |title=China Post Group sued by investors in joint venture |publisher=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/china-post-lawsuit-idUSL2N14X2FM20160113}}</ref>
== Background == China Horizon Investments Group was founded in January 2007 by Alan Clingman for the purpose of investing in the growth of Chinese domestic consumption projects alongside major Chinese entities, especially state-owned entities.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Chan |first1=Savio |last2=Zakkour |first2=Michael |year=2014 |title=China's Super Consumers: What 1 Billion Customers Want and How to Sell it to Them |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]] |pages=123-126 |isbn=9781118834749}}</ref>
China Post is the official postal service of China. The State Post Bureau of the People's Republic of China, the owner of China Post, is both a regulatory authority and government-owned enterprise. Thus, it is responsible for the regulation of the national postal industry and the management of national postal enterprises. China Post also owns one of China’s largest banks, the EMS courier service, an insurance company and a large-scale distribution business.
Following a multi-year pilot program, regulatory approvals for the China Horizon and China Post Joint Venture were granted in September 2015.
The scope of the joint venture is to build a modern distribution system for consumer products, expanding upon the extensive China Post network in order to bring a variety of safe, affordable and appropriate products (including a wide selection of Post Mart branded products) to rural China with the added ambition of improving the lives of rural citizens.
The joint venture has a registered capital of RMB 1 billion and has a license to use the China Post brand.
== Operations == Post Mart has established an efficient route to market sales and delivery system in Henan. It plans to roll this out nationally, reaching 10 provinces within five years. There are currently more than 50,000 village postal stations in Henan.
Post Mart operates a loyalty program called the Post Mart Emerald Club.
== Products == Post Mart provides a range of daily supply products such as cooking oil, rice, household goods, personal items and beverages such as Coca-Cola. Their brands include Chinese brands, international brands and its own brand.
== External links == * https://web.archive.org/web/20160304053517/http://www.china-postmart.com/en * http://www.china-horizon.com/
==References== {{reflist}}
{{China Postal System}}

{{Refimprove|date=November 2007}} {{Infobox U.S. legislation | shorttitle = Resource Conservation and Recovery Act | othershorttitles = Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976 | longtitle = An Act to provide technical and financial assistance for the development of management plans and facilities for the recovery of energy and other resources from discarded materials and for the safe disposal of discarded materials, and to regulate the management of hazardous waste. | colloquialacronym = RCRA | nickname = Solid Waste Utilization Act | enacted by = 94th | effective date = October 21, 1976 | public law url = http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/STATUTE-90/pdf/STATUTE-90-Pg2795.pdf | cite public law = 94-580 | cite statutes at large = {{usstat|90|2795}} | acts amended = [[Solid Waste Disposal Act of 1965]] | acts repealed = | title amended = [[Title 42 of the United States Code|42 U.S.C.: Public Health and Social Welfare]] | sections created = {{Usc-title-chap|42|82}} § 6901 et seq. | sections amended = | leghisturl = http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d094:SN02150:@@@R | introducedin = Senate | introducedbill = {{USBill|94|S.|2150}} | introducedby = [[Jennings Randolph]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]–[[West Virginia|WV]]) | introduceddate = July 21, 1975 | committees = [[Senate Public Works Committee]]; [[United States House Committee on Energy and Commerce|House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee]] | passedbody1 = Senate | passeddate1 = June 30, 1976 | passedvote1 = [http://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/94-1976/s977 88-3] | passedbody2 = House | passedas2 = | passeddate2 = September 27, 1976 | passedvote2 = [http://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/94-1976/h1235 367-8], in lieu of {{USBill|94|H.R.|14496}} | conferencedate = | passedbody3 = | passeddate3 = | passedvote3 = | agreedbody3 = Senate | agreeddate3 = September 30, 1976 | agreedvote3 = agreed | agreedbody4 = | agreeddate4 = | agreedvote4 = | passedbody4 = | passeddate4 = | passedvote4 = | signedpresident = [[Gerald Ford]] | signeddate = October 21, 1976 | unsignedpresident = | unsigneddate = | vetoedpresident = | vetoeddate = | overriddenbody1 = | overriddendate1 = | overriddenvote1 = | overriddenbody2 = | overriddendate2 = | overriddenvote2 = | amendments = | SCOTUS cases = }} The '''Resource Conservation and Recovery Act''' ('''RCRA'''), enacted in 1976, is the principal [[federal law]] in the [[United States]] governing the disposal of [[solid waste]] and [[hazardous waste]].Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, P.L. 94-580, {{USStat|90|2795}}, {{USC|42|6901}} ''et seq.,'' October 21, 1976. [http://epw.senate.gov/rcra.pdf RCRA Full text.] ==History and goals== [[United States Congress|Congress]] enacted RCRA to address the increasing problems the nation faced from its growing volume of municipal and industrial waste. RCRA amended the [[Solid Waste Disposal Act of 1965]]. It set national goals for: * Protecting [[human health]] and the [[natural environment]] from the potential hazards of waste disposal. * [[Energy conservation]] and [[natural resource]]s. * Reducing the amount of waste generated, through [[source reduction]] and [[recycling]] * Ensuring the [[waste management|management of waste]] in an environmentally sound manner.EPA (2010). [http://www.epa.gov/epawaste/laws-regs/rcrahistory.htm "History of RCRA."] It is now most widely known for the regulations promulgated under RCRA that set standards for the treatment, storage and disposal of [[hazardous waste]] in the United States. ==Implementation== The [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) has published waste management [[regulation]]s, which are codified in [[Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations]] at parts 239 through 282.EPA (2011). [http://www.epa.gov/epawaste/laws-regs/regs-non-haz.htm "Non-hazardous Waste Regulations."] Regulations regarding management of hazardous waste begin in part 260.EPA (2011). [http://www.epa.gov/epawaste/laws-regs/regs-haz.htm "Hazardous Waste Regulations."] As noted below, most [[U.S. state|states]] have enacted laws and created regulations that are at least as stringent as the federal regulations. Furthermore, the RCRA statute authorizes states to carry out many of the functions of the federal law through their own hazardous waste programs (as well as their state laws) if such programs have been approved by the EPA. ==Provisions== ===Subtitle A: General Provisions=== * Congressional Findings; Objectives and National Policy * Definitions * Interstate Cooperation; Application of Act and Integration with Other Acts * Financial Disclosure; Solid Waste Management Information and Guidelines ===Subtitle B: Office of Solid Waste; Authorities of the Administrator=== * Office of Solid Waste and Interagency Coordinating Committee * Authorities of EPA Administrator * Resource Recovery and Conservation Panels; Grants * Annual Report; Office of Ombudsman ===Subtitle C: "Cradle to Grave" requirements=== Arguably the most notable provisions of the RCRA statute are included in Subtitle C, which directs EPA to establish controls on the management of hazardous wastes from their point of generation, through their transportation and treatment, storage and/or disposal. Because RCRA requires controls on hazardous waste generators (i.e., sites that generate hazardous waste), transporters, and treatment, storage and disposal facilities (i.e., facilities that ultimately treat/dispose of or recycle the hazardous waste), the overall regulatory framework has become known as the "cradle to grave" system. The program imposes stringent recordkeeping and reporting requirements on generators, transporters, and operators of treatment, storage and disposal facilities handling hazardous waste. ===Subtitle D: Non-hazardous Solid Wastes=== Non-hazardous solid wastes include certain hazardous wastes which are exempted from the Subtitle C regulations, such as hazardous wastes from households and from conditionally exempt small quantity generators. Oil and gas exploration and production wastes, such as drill cuttings, produced water, and drilling fluids are categorized as "special wastes" and are also exempt from Subtitle C.{{cite web|url = http://www.epa.gov/osw/nonhaz/industrial/special/oil/oil-gas.pdf|title = Exemption of Oil and Gas Exploration and Production Wastes from Federal Hazardous Waste Regulations| publisher=Environmental Protection Agency Office of Solid Waste (5305W)}} Subtitle D also includes garbage (e.g., food containers, coffee grounds), non-recycled household appliances, residue from incinerated automobile tires, refuse such as metal scrap, construction materials, and [[sludge]] from [[industrial wastewater treatment|industrial]] and [[sewage treatment|municipal]] waste water facilities and [[water purification|drinking water treatment]] plants. ===Subtitle E: Department of Commerce responsibilities=== * Development of Specifications for secondary materials; Development of markets for recovered material. * Technology promotion ===Subtitle F: Federal responsibilities=== * Application of Federal, State and Local Law to Federal Facilities * Federal procurement * Cooperation with EPA; Applicability of solid waste disposal guidelines to executive agencies ===Subtitle G: Miscellaneous provisions=== * [[Whistleblower]] protection. Employees in the United States who believe they were fired or suffered another adverse action related to enforcement of this law have 30 days to file a written complaint with the [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]]. * Citizen Suits; Imminent Hazard suits * Petition for regulations; Public participation ===Subtitle H: Research, Development, Demonstration and Information=== * Research, Demonstrations, Training; Special Studies * Coordination, collection, dissemination of information ===Subtitle I: Underground Storage Tanks=== ;Background The operation of [[underground storage tanks]] (USTs) became subject to the RCRA regulatory program with enactment of the [[Hazardous and Solid Waste Amendments of 1984]] (HSWA).Hazardous and Solid Wastes Amendments of 1984, P.L. 98-616, {{USStat|98|3224}}, November 8, 1984. At that time there were about 2.1 million tanks subject to federal regulation, and the EPA program led to closure and removal of most substandard tanks.EPA (2011). [http://www.epa.gov/oust/overview.htm "Overview Of The Federal UST Program."] As of 2009 there were approximately 600,000 active USTs at 223,000 sites subject to federal regulation.U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Washington, D.C. (2010). [http://www.epa.gov/oust/pubs/fy09_annual_ust_report_3-10.pdf "FY 2009 Annual Report On The Underground Storage Tank Program."] Document no. EPA-510-R-10-001. ;Regulatory requirements The federal UST regulations cover tanks storing [[petroleum]] or listed hazardous substances, and define the [[Underground storage tank#Tank types|types]] of tanks permitted. EPA established a tank notification system to track UST status. UST regulatory programs are principally administered by state and U.S. territorial agencies.EPA (2009). [http://www.epa.gov/oust/aboutust.htm "Basic information about the Underground Storage Tank Program."] The regulations set standards for: * [[Groundwater]] monitoring * Double liners * Release detection, prevention and correction * Spill control * Overfill control (for petroleum products) * Restrictions on [[Land disposal unit|land disposal]] of untreatable hazardous waste products. The [[Superfund|Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act of 1986]] (SARA) required owners and operators of USTs to ensure corrective action is completed when a tank is in need of repair, or removal, when it is necessary to protect human health and the environment.Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act of 1986, P.L. 99-499, {{USStat|100|1696}}. October 17, 1986. It is also recommended that above-ground storage tanks are used whenever possible.{{cite book |title=Supervisors' Safety Manual |edition=9th |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1997 |publisher=National Safety Council |location=Itasca, IL |isbn=978-0-87912-197-6 |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}{{cite journal |title=Chemicals Stored in USTs: Characteristics and Leak Detection |year=1991 |publisher=United States Environmental Protection Agency, Risk Reduction Engineering Laboratory |location=Washington, DC |url=http://nepis.epa.gov/Exe/ZyNET.exe/2000TMBV.TXT?ZyActionD=ZyDocument&Client=EPA&Index=1991+Thru+1994&Docs=&Query=&Time=&EndTime=&SearchMethod=1&TocRestrict=n&Toc=&TocEntry=&QField=&QFieldYear=&QFieldMonth=&QFieldDay=&IntQFieldOp=0&ExtQFieldOp=0&XmlQuery=&File=D%3A%5Czyfiles%5CIndex%20Data%5C91thru94%5CTxt%5C00000015%5C2000TMBV.txt&User=ANONYMOUS&Password=anonymous&SortMethod=h%7C-&MaximumDocuments=1&FuzzyDegree=0&ImageQuality=r75g8/r75g8/x150y150g16/i425&Display=p%7Cf&DefSeekPage=x&SearchBack=ZyActionL&Back=ZyActionS&BackDesc=Results%20page&MaximumPages=1&ZyEntry=1&SeekPage=x&ZyPURL#}} ===Subtitle J: Medical Waste (expired)=== RCRA Subtitle J regulated medical waste in four states ([[New York (state)|New York]], [[New Jersey]], [[Connecticut]], [[Rhode Island]]) and [[Puerto Rico]], and expired on March 22, 1991. (''See'' [[Medical Waste Tracking Act]].)EPA (2010). [http://www.epa.gov/waste/nonhaz/industrial/medical/tracking.htm "Medical Waste Tracking Act of 1988."] 2010-01-20. If determined to be hazardous, medical waste is currently regulated by RCRA Subtitle C for hazardous wastes. ==Amendments and related legislation== The [[Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act]] (CERCLA), also known as "Superfund," was enacted in 1980 to address the problem of remediating abandoned hazardous waste sites, by establishing [[legal liability]], as well as a trust fund for cleanup activities.Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, P.L. 96-510, {{USStat|94|2767}}, {{USC|42|9601}} ''et seq.,'' December 11, 1980. In general CERCLA applies to contaminated sites, while RCRA's focus is on controlling the ongoing generation and management of particular waste streams. RCRA, like CERCLA, has provisions to require cleanup of contaminated sites that occurred in the past. In 1984 Congress expanded the scope of RCRA with the enactment of Hazardous and Solid Waste Amendments (HSWA). The amendments strengthened the law by covering small quantity generators of hazardous waste and establishing requirements for hazardous waste [[incineration|incinerators]], and the closing of substandard [[landfills]]. In 1986, SARA addressed cleanup of leaking USTs and other leaking waste storage facilities. The amendments established a [[trust (property)|trust]] fund to pay for the cleanup of leaking UST sites where responsible parties cannot be identified.EPA (2011). [http://www.epa.gov/oust/ltffacts.htm "Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund."] The Land Disposal Program Flexibility Act of 1996 allowed some flexibility in the procedures for land disposal of certain wastes. For example, a waste is not subject to land disposal restrictions if it is sent to an [[industrial wastewater treatment]] facility, a municipal [[sewage treatment]] plant, or is treated in a "zero discharge" facility.Land Disposal Program Flexibility Act of 1996, P.L. 104-119, {{USStat|110|830}}, {{USC|42|6924}}. March 26, 1996. The bill [[Reducing Excessive Deadline Obligations Act of 2013 (H.R. 2279; 113th Congress)]], which made it to the House floor in January 2014, would amend this law "to remove a requirement that the Administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) review and revise regulations declared under such Act at least every three years."{{cite web|title=H.R. 2279 - Summary|url=http://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th/house-bill/2279|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=7 January 2014}} ==Treatment, storage, and disposal facility permits== {{Expand section|date=May 2008}} Treatment, storage, and disposal facilities (TSDFs) manage hazardous waste under RCRA Subtitle C and generally must have a permit in order to operate. While most facilities have RCRA permits, some continue to operate under what is called "interim status." Interim status requirements appear in 40 CFR Part 265.EPA. [http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr&sid=385ea9ac5d6e0fb83be2351f0836eb09&rgn=div5&view=text&node=40:25.0.1.1.6&idno=40 "Part 265 – Interim Status Standards For Owners And Operators Of Hazardous Waste Treatment, Storage, And Disposal Facilities."] {{USCFR|40|265}}. The permitting requirements for TSDFs appear in 40 CFR Parts 264 and 270.EPA. [http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr&sid=385ea9ac5d6e0fb83be2351f0836eb09&rgn=div5&view=text&node=40:25.0.1.1.5&idno=40 "Part 264 – Standards For Owners And Operators Of Hazardous Waste Treatment, Storage, And Disposal Facilities."] {{USCFR|40|264}}.
[http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr&sid=58204e14b6f985f03d09f71e683c830c&rgn=div5&view=text&node=40:26.0.1.1.4&idno=40 "Part 270 – EPA Administered Permit Programs: The Hazardous Waste Permit Program ."] {{USCFR|40|270}}. TSDFs manage (treat, store, or dispose) hazardous waste in units that may include: container storage areas, tanks, surface impoundments, waste piles, land treatment units, landfills, incinerators, containment buildings, and/or drip pads. The unit-specific permitting and operational requirements are described in further detail in 40 CFR Part 264, Subparts J through DD. ==See also== * [[Clean Water Act]] * [[Formerly Used Defense Sites]] * [[Hazardous waste in the United States]] * [[Solid waste policy in the United States]] * [[Uranium Mill Tailings Radiation Control Act]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{wikisource-inline|Resource Conservation and Recovery Act}} * [http://www.epa.gov/rcraonline RCRA Online: database of documents covering a wide range of RCRA issues and topics] * [http://www.epa.gov/epawaste/hazard/tsd/permit/prmtguid.htm "Hazardous Waste Permitting Process: A Citizens Guide"] - EPA * [http://sanjour.info Collected Papers of William Sanjour], a retired EPA employee and whistleblower {{US Environmental law}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Resource Conservation And Recovery Act}} [[Category:1976 in law]] [[Category:94th United States Congress]] [[Category:United States business law]] [[Category:First Amendment to the United States Constitution]] [[Category:Public administration]] [[Category:United States Environmental Protection Agency]] [[Category:United States federal environmental legislation]] [[Category:Waste legislation in the United States]] [[Category:Whistleblower protection legislation]] [[Category:1976 in the environment]]

revision.text:
'''Richard Beckhard''' (1918–1999) was an American [[organizational theorist]], [[Adjunct Professor#Adjunct professor|Adjunct Professor]] at MIT, and pioneer in the field of [[organization development]].
Beckhard co-launched the ''Addison-Wesley Organization Development Series'' and began the ''Organization Development Network'' in 1967.<ref>[http://www.odnetwork.org/ Organization Development Network]</ref> His classic work, ''Organization Development: Strategies and Models,'' was published in 1969. Beckhard was an adjunct professor at the [[MIT Sloan School of Management]] from 1963-1984. He died on December 28, 1999.<ref>[http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2000/beckhard-0126.html Richard Beckhard Obituary, MIT]</ref>
He helped to define [[organization development]] as: "an effort (1) planned, (2) organization-wide, (3) managed from the top, to (4) increase organization effectiveness and health through (5) planned interventions in the organization's 'processes', using behavioural-science knowledge".<ref>Beckhard, R., 1969, p. 9. Organization Development: Strategies and Models</ref>
Together with [[David Gleicher]], he is credited with developing a [[Formula for Change]]. The formula proposes that the combination of organisational dissatisfaction, vision for the future and the possibility of immediate, tactical action must be stronger than the resistance within the organisation in order for meaningful change to occur.
Beckhard is also credited for developing the ''GRPI model'' which highlights four key conditions (Growth, Roles, Processes, Interpersonal) for team effectiveness.<ref>Beckhard, R. (1972). Optimizing Team Building Efforts. Journal of Contemporary Business, pp. 23–27. Credit to Beckhard and citation as under: {{cite web|author=Douglas O’Loughlin|url=http://www.cscollege.gov.sg/Knowledge/Pages/Creating-Teams-That-Work.aspx|title=Creating Teams That Work — A Position Paper on Team Effectiveness|date=August 2013|accessdate=7 December 2014}}</ref>
== Selected publications == ;Books, a selection * Beckhard, Richard. "Organization development: Strategies and models." (1969). * Beckhard, Richard, and Reuben T. Harris. ''Organizational transitions: Managing complex change''. Reading, MA: Addison-Wesley, 1977. * Beckhard, Richard, and Wendy Pritchard. ''Changing the essence: The art of creating and leading fundamental change in organizations''. Vol. 10. San Francisco: Jossey-Bass, 1992. * [[Hesselbein, Frances]], [[Marshall Goldsmith]], and Richard Beckhard. The leader of the future. Jossey Bass, 1996.
;Articles, a selection * Beckhard, Richard, and Gibb Dyer Jr. "Managing continuity in the family-owned business." ''Organizational Dynamics'' 12.1 (1983): 5-12.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{authority control}}

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Small and medium-sized enterprises]]; added [[Category:Organizations related to small and medium-sized enterprises]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{COI|date=June 2015}} {{notability|Products|date=June 2015}} {{unreferenced|date=June 2015}} {{Orphan|date=October 2015}} }} '''SME Toolkit''' is a project of [[International Finance Corporation]] (IFC), a member of the World Bank Group, that - in partnership with [[IBM]] - helps entrepreneurs and small and medium enterprises (SMEs) all over the world to learn and implement sustainable business management practices and increase their productivity, efficiency, and capacity, as well as improve their access to finance and new markets.
== Content ==
=== Global Content === SME Toolkit consists of a large body of globally relevant free content for SMEs provided by content partners, and includes over 5,000 business forms, tools, how-to-articles, business software and advice about starting and growing a business. The areas covered include accounting, finance, human resources, international business, legal, insurance, marketing, sales, operations and technology. SME Toolkit collaborates with major global partners, including [[IBM]], [[ICICI Bank]], [[American Express]], My Own Business, and [[Visa Inc.|Visa]] to offer users a large set of small business content, and a number of other services.
=== Local Content === In addition to global content, SME Toolkit local websites offer information on local business news, events, and regulations. Users can register and log in, find business partners, list in an online SME directory, create a hosted web page for their business, and participate in multilingual social networks on key business topics. IFC partners with key institutions in target local markets to manage, localize and distribute localized versions of the Toolkit.
== Features ==
=== Training Curriculum === The Toolkit also offers a business training curriculum on improving business management practices and overall business performance using computer-based tools. The workshops are available to business development service (BDS) providers and SMEs in key markets.
=== Multiple Delivery Platforms === A web interface allows users to search or browse to locate content. To enable increased dissemination and access in countries with limited computer access and Internet connectivity, SME Toolkit content is also offered on mobile platforms, in the form of a CD-ROM, and via text messages (SMS).
== Distribution == SME Toolkit has been launched in 16 languages (English, Spanish, French, Portuguese, Russian, Ukrainian, Mongolian, Arabic, Hindi, Tamil, Sinhalese, Sri Lankan Tamil, Indonesian Bahasa, Chinese, Vietnamese and Georgian) in more than 41 markets. SME Toolkit web sites receive more than 6.7 million users per year.
== References == <references />
==External links== *[http://www.smetoolkit.org SME Toolkit]
[[Category:International development programs]] [[Category:World Bank]] [[Category:Organizations related to small and medium-sized enterprises]]

'''Statements on Auditing Procedure''' were issued by the Committee on Auditing Procedure of the AICPA from 1939 to 1972. The Committee issued 54 SAPs before it became the Auditing Standards Executive Committee (AcSEC) and began issuing [[Statements on Auditing Standards (USA)|Statements on Auditing Standards]].[http://clio.lib.olemiss.edu/u?/SAS,0 Statement on Auditing Standards No. 1] summarized and superseded the 54 SAPs.

full-text]||align="center" |1972 November |}
==History of Statements on Auditing Procedure== The history of the Statements on Auditing Procedures began in 1917 when the American Institute of Accountants (the predecessor organization for the AICPA) was asked by the Federal Trade Commission to prepare a "memorandum on balance-sheet audits." The resulting document was published in the April 1917 issue of the [[Federal Reserve Bulletin]]<ref>"Uniform Accounting: a tentative proposal submitted by the Federal Reserve Board." ''[[Federal Reserve Bulletin]]'' April 1917 [http://umiss.lib.olemiss.edu:82/record=b1010875 full-test]</ref> and reissued in 1918 as a pamphlet.<ref>''Approved methods for the preparation of balance sheet statements.'' 1918 [http://umiss.lib.olemiss.edu:82/record=b1010874 full-text]</ref> In 1929 the pamphlet was again revised.<ref>''Verification of financial statements.'' United States. Federal Reserve Board, 1929 [http://umiss.lib.olemiss.edu:82/record=b1012357 full-text]</ref> A third revision was done in 1936.<ref>''Examination of financial statements by independent public accountants.'' American Institute of Accountants, 1936 [http://umiss.lib.olemiss.edu:82/record=b1035146 full-text]</ref>
The Institute determined that, rather than reissuing the 1936 pamphlet, it would, through the Committee on Auditing Procedure, issue Statements on Auditing Procedure that modified and superseded parts of the 1936 pamphlet. The SAPs were "designed to guide the auditor in those areas of specific situations encountered in practice in which he must exercise judgment, situations outside the realm of textbooks, whose function is inherently to describe procedures in general."<ref>''Codification of statements on auditing procedure, based on statements 1 to 24 (1939 to 1949).'' American Institute of Accountants, 1951, p. 7 [http://clio.lib.olemiss.edu/u?/deloitte,11723 full-text]</ref> By 1948, the 1936 pamphlet was considered so out-of-date that it was withdrawn from publication.
In 1951, the first 24 ''Statements on Auditing Procedure'' were codified <ref>''Codification of Statements on Auditing Procedure, Based on Statements 1 to 24 (1939 to 1949).'' American Institute of Accountants, 1951 [http://clio.lib.olemiss.edu/u?/deloitte,11723 full-text]</ref> The ''Codification'' also contains a summary history of the process of standardizing auditing practice up to 1951 (see pp. 5–8).
In 1954, the Committee on Auditing Procedure finished work on the booklet ''Generally Accepted Auditing Standards: Their Significance and Scope.''<ref>''Generally Accepted Auditing Standards: Their Significance and Scope.'' American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, 1954 [http://clio.lib.olemiss.edu/u?/deloitte,40861 full-text]</ref> This publication responded to the Securities and Exchange Commission's recommendation that the auditor's report make a representation as to compliance with generally accepted auditing standards.<ref>''Codification of statements on auditing procedure, based on statements 1 to 24 (1939 to 1949).'' American Institute of Accountants, 1951, p. 6 [http://clio.lib.olemiss.edu/u?/deloitte,11723 full-text]</ref>
Statement on Procedure no. 33 again codified previous Committee on Auditing Procedure publications, including the 1951 ''Codification'', The 1954 ''Generally Accepted Auditing Standards,'' and ''Statements on Auditing Procedure'' 25-32.
The final publication of the Committee on Auditing procedure, ''Codification of Auditing Standards and Procedures 1,''<ref>''Statement on Auditing Standards, no. 1.'' American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, 1973 [http://clio.lib.olemiss.edu/u?/SAS,0 full-text]</ref> superseded SAPs 33-54. The Statement is now known as ''Statement on Auditing Standards, no. 1'' and began a series of Statements on Auditing Standards'' (SASs) that are still being issued by the Auditing Standards Board. See [[Statements on Auditing Standards (USA)]]. Beginning in 1976, these Standards were codified annually as section AU of the ''AICPA's Professional Standards.''
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.aicpa.org American Institute of Certified Public Accountants]
[[Category:Auditing standards]] [[Category:Auditing in the United States]]

{{Infobox person | name = Stella Chinyelu Okoli | honorific_suffix = [[Order of the Niger|OON]], [[Orders, decorations, and medals of Nigeria|MON]] | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by the blind and visually impaired's speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1944||}} | birth_place = [[Kano State]], [[Nigeria]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = [[Nigerian]] | other_names = | alma_mater = {{plainlist| *[[University of Bradford]] *[[Chelsea College of Science and Technology|Chelsea College (University of London)]]}} | occupation = {{flatlist| *[[Pharmacist]] *[[entrepreneur]]}} | years_active = 1976–present | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''Stella Chinyelu Okoli''' ([[Orders, decorations, and medals of Nigeria|MON]], [[Order of the Niger|OON]]) (born {{circa|1944}})<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenationonlineng.net/stella-okoli-70/|title=Stella Okoli @70|work=[[The Nation (Nigeria)|The Nation Newspaper]]|date=6 August 2014|accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref> is a [[Nigerian]] [[pharmacist]] and [[entrepreneur]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenationonlineng.net/stella-okoli-in-low-70th-birthday-celebration/|title=Stella Okoli in low 70th birthday celebration|work=[[The Nation (Nigeria)|The Nation Newspaper]]|date=9 August 2014|accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref> She is the founder and current C.E.O of [[Emzor Pharmaceutical]], a pharmaceutical manufacturing company.<ref name="ynaija">{{cite news|url=http://www.ynaija.com/men-and-women-of-excellence-full-list-of-nominees-for-the17th-thisday-annual-awards/|title=Women of distinction! Sefi Atta, Toyosi Akerele, Diezani Alison-Madueke, Florence It-Giwa & others to be honoured at the 17th ThisDay Annual Awards – See The Full List|work=[[YNaija]]|last=Inyang|first=Ifreke|date=3 February 2012|accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Stella was born in [[Kano State]], [[Northern Nigeria]] into the family of Felix Ebelechukwu and Margaret Modebelu, descents of [[Nnewi]] in [[Anambra State]].<ref name="thisday"/> She started her [[formal education]] in 1954 after enrolling as a pupil at All Saint Primary School, [[Onitsha]] before proceeding to complete her [[Secondary education|secondary school education]] in 1964 at Ogidi Girls Secondary School, [[Ogidi, Anambra|Ogidi]].<ref name="thisday">{{cite news|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/stella-okoli-shocks-family-and-friends/187227|title=Stella Okoli Shocks Family and Friends|work=[[Thisday|ThisDay Newspaper]]|date=24 August 2014|accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref>
In 1969, Stella graduated from the [[University of Bradford]] after studying [[Pharmacy]]. She also holds an M.Sc certificate in [[Biopharmaceutical]] after graduating from the [[University of London]], [[Chelsea College of Science and Technology|Chelsea College]] in 1971.<ref name="emerald">{{cite web|url=http://www.emeraldngr.com/documents/49.html|title=Profile of Dr. Stella Okoli|publisher=Emerald Energy Resources Limited|accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref>
==Career== Prior to the establishment of [[Emzor Pharmaceutical]], Stella had worked in several pharmaceutical firms including [[Middlesex Hospital|Middlesex Hospital, London]], [[Boots UK|Boots the Chemists Limited]] and Pharma-Deko.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestreetjournal.org/2011/09/meet-nigerias-most-influential-women/|title=Meet Nigeria’s Most Influential Women|publisher=The Street Journal|date=30 September 2011|accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref>
In January 1977, Stella started Emzor Pharmaceutical with the initial name "Emzor Chemists Limited" as a small pharmacy retail shop in [[Somolu]], [[Lagos State]].<ref name="mirror">{{cite news|url=http://www.nationalmirroronline.net/new/nigerias-lady-of-drugs/|title=Nigeria’s ‘lady of drugs’|work=[[National Mirror|National Mirror Newspaper]]|last=Osunnuyi|first=Adejuwon|date=30 November 2015|accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref> Emzor Pharmaceutical has since become one of the leading pharmaceutical companies in Nigeria with over 50 products since its incorporation in 1984.<ref name="mirror"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenationonlineng.net/i-strive-to-make-people-happy/|title=‘I strive to make people happy’|work=[[The Nation (Nigeria)|The Nation Newspaper]]|date=12 October 2014|accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref>
A current member of the Economic Summit of Nigeria and the Health Matters Advisory Board of Nigeria, Stella currently serves as the Vice President of Manufacturers Association of Nigeria and the Nigerian Association of Chambers of Commerce, Industry, Mines and Agriculture having served as Chairman of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Group and the Manufacturers Association of Nigeria.<ref name="emerald"/>
==Philanthropy== After the death of her son Chike Okoli in 2005, Stella started the Chike Okoli Foundation in 2006 as a [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit organisation]] founded with the aim of fighting poverty and diseases by raising awareness on [[cardiovascular diseases]]. She also runs the Chike Okoli Centre for Entrepreneurial Studies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.venturesafrica.com/to-make-or-not-to-make-stella-okoli-emzor-pharmaceuticals/|title=To Make Or Not To Make: Stella Okoli, Emzor Pharmaceuticals|publisher=Ventures Africa|accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2012/06/why-we-fight-poverty-heart-diseases-stella-okoli-md-emzor/|title=Why we fight poverty, heart diseases – Stella Okoli, MD, Emzor|work=[[Vanguard (Nigeria)|Vanguard Newspaper]]|date=2 June 2012|last=Ayobami|first=John|accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref>
==Accolades and recognitions== In recognition for her achievements and contributions to the health sector in Nigeria, Stella was bestowed with the [[Orders, decorations, and medals of Nigeria|Member of the Order of the Niger]] award. In 2012, she was honoured at the 17th [[Thisday|ThisDay]] Annual Awards.<ref name="ynaija"/> She is also a recipient of the ECOWAS International Gold Award.<ref name="mirror"/>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Infobox Officeholder |image = Major General Miranda Marin.jpg | name = William Miranda Marín | caption = | order =23rd [[List of mayors of Caguas, Puerto Rico|Mayor of Caguas, Puerto Rico]] | term_start = 1997 | term_end = 2010 | predecessor = [[Ángel O. Berríos]] | successor = [[William Miranda Torres]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1940|9|23}} | birth_place = [[Caguas, Puerto Rico]] |death_date= {{death date and age|2010|6|4|1940|9|23|mf=y}} |death_place= [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]], [[Puerto Rico]] | constituency = | party = [[Popular Democratic Party of Puerto Rico|Popular Democratic Party]] (PPD) | spouse = Carmen Sara Torres | profession = [[Accountant]], [[Lawyer]], [[General]] | religion = [[Roman Catholic]] | nickname = "Willie" | allegiance = {{flagicon|United States}} [[United States|United States of America]] | branch = [[File:US Army National Guard Insignia.svg|15x15px]] [[Army National Guard]] | serviceyears = 1959-1993 | rank = [[Image:US-O8 insignia.svg|35px]]
[[Major general (United States)|Major General]] | commands = [[Puerto Rico Adjutant General|Adjutant General]] of the [[Puerto Rico National Guard]] }} '''William "Willie" Miranda Marín''' {{Spanish name|'''Miranda'''|'''Marín'''|plain=yes}} (September 23, 1940 – June 4, 2010) was the [[mayor]] of [[Caguas, Puerto Rico|Caguas]], [[Puerto Rico]] from 1997 until his death in 2010. ==Personal life== The son of José Miranda Gómez, a [[sugar cane]] cutter, and Rafaela Marín, a tobacco stripper, Miranda Marín was born in the Tomás de Castro sector of rural Caguas.{{cite news | first=José L. | last=Carmona | author= | url=http://www.puertorico-herald.org/issues/2002/vol6n51/CBMarinPersonYear-en.html | title=Person Of The Year, Public Sector: William Miranda Marin | publisher=Caribbean Business | date=November 28, 2002 | accessdate=2006-04-29 }} and graduated from the José Gautier Benítez High School in Caguas in 1957. Four years later, he earned a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[Accounting]] from the [[University of Puerto Rico at Río Piedras]]. In 1969 he completed his Juris Doctor at the [[University of Puerto Rico at Río Piedras]] and was admitted to the bar in 1970. Miranda Marín and his wife had three children: [[William Miranda Torres|William Edgardo]], Luis Alexander, and José Juan . They resided in the sector of [[Bairoa, Caguas, Puerto Rico|Bairoa]] in Caguas. On September 18, 2009, Miranda Marín announced he was diagnosed with [[Pancreatic cancer]].{{cite news | url=http://www.primerahora.com/diario/noticia/politica/noticias/confirman_miranda_marin_tiene_cancer_en_el_pancreas/331963 | title=Confirman William Miranda Marín tiene cáncer en el páncreas | publisher=Primera Hora | date=September 18, 2009 | accessdate=2010-02-26 }} On June 4, 2010 at 7:45 in the morning, Miranda Marín died in the Auxilio Mutuo Hospital in San Juan, Puerto Rico after battling his illness. ==Businessman== Miranda Marín held top positions at Empresas Díaz and the San Juan Cement Co. from 1979 to 1990, among them treasurer, executive vice-president, and co-chairman of the board. Before seeking public office for the first time in 1996, he devoted three years to housing and commercial development. Miranda Marín also served as member and treasurer of the board of the Puerto Rico Health Services Corp., as chairman of the board of the San Juan Children's Choir, and as chairman of the board of the Community Services Institute. ==Political career and public service== He served as executive vice president of the Government Development Bank from 1973 to 1975, as executive director of the [[Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority]] from 1975 to 1976, and He also served as executive director of the Office for Improvement of the Public Schools of Puerto Rico from 1990 to 1992. Miranda Marín also was the chairman of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|U.S. Democratic Party]] Chapter of Puerto Rico, secretary-general of the [[Popular Democratic Party of Puerto Rico]] (PPD), chairman of the PPD Status Commission, and president of the [[Puerto Rico Mayors Association]]. Until his death, he was chairman of the board of the Municipal Revenue Collections Center (CRIM by its acronym in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]). His candidacy had been considered by the Popular Democratic Party (PPD by its acronym in Spanish) to be a viable contender for the Governorship of Puerto Rico. ==Military career== William Miranda Marín served for 36 years in the [[Puerto Rico National Guard]] starting as Private E-1 enlisted citizen-soldier in 1959 until his retirement in 1993 as the [[Puerto Rico Adjutant General|Adjutant General of the Puerto Rico National Guard]] with the rank of [[Major General]] (1990–1992). While commanding the Puerto Rico National Guard, MG William Miranda Marín founded the PRNG Institutional Trust (FIGNA). Miranda Marín retired from the Puerto Rico Army National Guard in 1993. ==Military awards== *[[File:Meritorious Service Medal ribbon.svg|60px]]  [[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Service Medal]] *[[File:Army Commendation Medal ribbon.svg|60px]]  [[Army Commendation Medal]] *[[File:Army_Achievement_Medal_ribbon.svg|60px]]  [[Army Achievement Medal]] *[[File:National Defense Service Medal ribbon.svg|60px]]  [[National Defense Service Medal]] *[[File:Armed_Forces_Reserve_Medal_ribbon.svg|60px]]  [[Armed Forces Reserve Medal]] *[[File:Army_Service_Ribbon.svg|60px]]  [[Army Service Ribbon]] *[[File:Army_Reserve_Overseas_Training_Ribbon.svg|60px]]  [[Army Reserve Components Overseas Training Ribbon]] '''Puerto Rico National Guard decorations''' *[[File:Merit_Cross.JPG|60px]]  Puerto Rico National Guard Merit Cross *[[File:Service_Medal1.JPG|60px]]  Puerto Rico National Guard Service Medal *[[File:Exemplary Conduct Medal.JPG|60px]]  Puerto Rico National Guard Exemplary Conduct Ribbon *[[File:Civil Disturbance Ribbon.JPG|60px]]  Puerto Rico National Guard Civil Disturbance Ribbon *[[File:Disaster Relief Ribbon.JPG|60px]]  Puerto Rico National Guard Disaster Relief Ribbon == Political Views == Miranda Marín's views were regarded as ''soberanista,'' which seeks more sovereign political powers from the US outside the current framework of E.L.A. ([[Estado Libre Asociado]]). ===Mayor of Caguas=== On January 13, 1997 Miranda Marín became the mayor of Caguas and had since won re-election in 2000, 2004 and 2008. ==Legacy== The building of the institutional trust of the National Guard of Puerto Rico on [[Puerto Rico Highway 1|State Road #1]] from Caguas to Río Piedras at the former facilities of Euro Bank, was posthumously named General William Miranda Marín. ==See also== {{Portal|Puerto Rico|United States Army|Biography}} *[[List of famous Puerto Ricans]] *[[List of Puerto Rican military personnel]] *[[Puerto Rico Adjutant General]] {{Clear}} ==Notes== ==References== {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before= [[Ángel O.
